### Prerequisites

This text is a continuation of *Expanding* text (<htcite0>). Therefore, we suggest studying it before moving on.

### Introduction

When we focus too much on something, we risk not noticing what is around us. Let us look again at the example of the sheet divided into two halves, separated in the center:

Divided Sheet

Table 1: Sheet divided into two parts, separated in the center.
When observing Table 1, we notice that the two sides are separated by a central line. Let’s carry out another exercise with these sheets:

Practice 1: The Third Part

1. If you don’t have the sheet you previously divided, take a new one and cut it in two.
2. Bring the two parts as close together as possible. Notice that, even so, there is still something separating them in the center.
3. Now, hold one part in each hand and move them as far apart as you can. At this stage, it becomes clear that there is much more than just two sides — which have now become extremes.
This practice, together with the previous texts, leads us to an initial reflection:

Reflection 1: On Extremes

When we see only ourselves and an opposing side, could this lead us to extremes?

### Human Body

To better understand the division into three in our daily lives, let’s begin by observing the human body, shown in **Figure 1**:
Figure 1: Human Body. © History Tracers. .
For didactic purposes, we can imagine the human body divided into three parts:

Body partDescription
Head (1)The upper region of the body, where the eyes, nose, and mouth are located.
TrunkIncludes the neck (2), chest (3), abdomen (4), and pelvis (5).
LimbsComprising the arms (6), hands (7), legs (8), and feet (9).

Table 2: Description of the regions of the human body.

Despite the initial division into three parts, we use nine numbers to represent the internal regions within these divisions. As we move forward in our study, we will further detail and better understand each part of the human body.

### The Number Three among Indigenous Peoples

In the previous text, we saw, for example, the understanding of the universe divided into underworld, earth, and heavens in the Mesoamerican ballgame (<htcite0>). However, these were not the only contexts in which the number three was adopted by Indigenous peoples.

#### Cuisine

When analyzing the tools used in food preparation, such as the metate in Teotihuacan, Mexico, we observe that they had a supporting tripod:
Figure 2: Metate from Mexico. Photo taken on , during a visit to the Achaeological Site of Teotihuacan, México (INAH. Teotihuacan).
text.imgdesc: In this metate, we see two front supports (“legs”) and a rear support located at the center of a curved rectangular piece. On the top, there is a roller used to grind corn.

text.text: Still in Mesoamerica (*Abya Yala*), according to the classification proposed by W. Creamer (<htcite0>), we also find ceramic vessels with tripods, such as those discovered in Costa Rica:

#### E-Group Complexes

The E-Group complexes, found in different regions of Mesoamerica (*Abya Yala*), have not yet been fully understood (<htcite0>). However, some studies suggest that they may have been used to measure the seasons of the year (<htcite1>). If this is confirmed, we would have an interesting scenario in which the four seasons of the year were represented in a structure consisting of only three elevated constructions. These, in turn, would have marked the solstices—days with the longest or shortest nights, depending on the Earth’s position—and the equinoxes, when day and night are of equal length (<htcite2>).
Video 1: Type E Complex in Caracol, Belize. Recorded during a visit to the site on .

### Excavating

When we have an idea of what cultures or objects are like, by analyzing only a part we can imagine the whole. This happens in different areas of science. In this text, we will focus on archaeology.

Before continuing, let’s reflect for a moment:

Reflection 2: Eureka

When we find parts of something, is it possible to reconstruct it?

Is it possible to have a mistaken idea when observing only a part?

#### Inside an excavation

When an excavation begins at an archaeological site, it is not possible to know exactly all the objects that will be found. Still, we can have a general idea of what might appear if we know the related cultures.

**Figure 4** shows the excavation of a sacred mountain (Witz) in San Andrés, El Salvador (*Witz*) in San Andrés, El Salvador (<htcite0>; <htcite1>). In it we can see that the structure was completely covered with earth over time.
Figure 4: Photo taken at the San Andrés Archaeological Park on , during a visit to the site (Parque Arqueológico San Andrés).

The process of excavating structures is slow and careful, avoiding, among other things, breaking pieces. **Figure 5** shows an excavation at Cahal Pech, Belize (<htcite0>), with the tools used for the work. As can be seen, they are manual tools such as a bucket, shovel, and hammer.

### Reconstructing the excavation

Despite all the knowledge and techniques applied to carry out excavations and preserve artifacts, it is still common to find objects that are broken or deformed by time. In this scenario, we need to rely on knowledge acquired from other sites and prior research in order to reconstruct these pieces.

#### Study scenario

Since Belize is also part of Mesoamerica (Abya Yala), we can turn to prior knowledge about pieces from the region to begin reconstructing those found broken in excavations.

In a real scenario, we would first use data from the same site and then from nearby ones. But, since this is an educational text, we have the freedom to go a little further and explore broader connections.

#### Mapping

In Teotihuacan, to the north, and in Costa Rica, to the south, pieces with three supports have been found. Let us suppose, then, that we have pieces similar to those in **Figure 3**, all broken, and that we need to reconstruct them.

When separating the pieces into groups, we observed a total of 27 supports (“legs”) among the objects.

Reflection 3: Reconstructing

We know that each piece uses 3 supports. With 27 supports available, how many complete pieces can we assemble?

exercise_v2.question: Nosso corpo possuí mais que duas divisões?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: Neste texto, opitamos por separar o corpo em 3 partes, mas nada impede que possamos mapeá-los em mais parte, para poder explicá-lo melhor.

exercise_v2.question: Dividir em apenas dois explicatudo?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: Mesmo quando dividimos uma folha em apenas dois pedaços, foi possível ver que por melhor que aproximássemos, ainda temos um centro, um terceiro elemento. Logo, dividir em apenas dois pode ser apenas uma simplificação que pode omitir detalhes.
